title: An Introduction to Estimating Joint Probability Models with `iglm`
text: vignette provides introduction iglm package, designed estimating joint probability models incorporate network structures. package allows users analyze individual attributes network connections jointly influence outcomes interest.

title: An Introduction to Estimating Joint Probability Models with `iglm`
text: use iglm package, first need load R session Next, can create iglm object specifying network structure attributes interest. simple example:
code: library(iglm) n_actors =100  attribute_info = rnorm(n_actors) attribute_cov = diag(attribute_info) edge_cov = outer(attribute_info, attribute_info, FUN = function(x,y){abs(x-y)}) set.seed(123)  alpha = 0.3 block <- matrix(nrow = 50, ncol = 50, data = 1) neighborhood <- as.matrix(Matrix::bdiag(replicate(n_actors/50, block, simplify=FALSE)))  overlapping_degree = 0.5 neighborhood = matrix(nrow = n_actors, ncol = n_actors, data = 0) block <- matrix(nrow = 5, ncol = 5, data = 0) size_neighborhood = 5 size_overlap = ceiling(size_neighborhood*overlapping_degree)  end = floor((n_actors-size_neighborhood)/size_overlap) for(i in 0:end){   neighborhood[(1+size_overlap*i):(size_neighborhood+size_overlap*i), (1+size_overlap*i):(size_neighborhood+size_overlap*i)] = 1 } neighborhood[(n_actors-size_neighborhood+1):(n_actors), (n_actors-size_neighborhood+1):(n_actors)] = 1  type_x <- "binomial" type_y <- "binomial" formula_beg = as.formula("xyz_obj ~ 1 ") formula_model = as.formula("xyz_object ~ 1 ")  object = netplus(neighborhood = neighborhood, directed = F, type_x = type_x, type_y = type_y)

title: An Introduction to Estimating Joint Probability Models with `iglm`
text: can specify model formula includes various network statistics attribute effects. example: fully define model, need set sampler MCMC estimation set necessary parameters:
code: formula <- object ~ edges(mode = "local") + attribute_y + attribute_x + popularity # Parameters of edges(mode = "local"), attribute_y, and attribute_x gt_coef = c(3,-1,-1) # Parameters for popularity effect gt_coef_pop =  c(rnorm(n = n_actors, -2, 1)) # Define the sampler sampler_tmp = sampler.iglm(n_burn_in = 100, n_simulation = 10,                                sampler.x = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals =  n_actors*10,seed = 13),                                sampler.y = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals =  n_actors*10, seed = 32),                                sampler.z = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = sum(neighborhood>0)*10, seed = 134),                                init_empty = F)  model_tmp_new <- iglm(formula = formula,                            coef = gt_coef,  coef_popularity = gt_coef_pop, sampler = sampler_tmp,                            control = control.iglm(accelerated = F,max_it = 200, display_progress = T, var = T))

title: An Introduction to Estimating Joint Probability Models with `iglm`
text: specified model, can simulate new data based fitted parameters:
code: # Simulate new networks model_tmp_new$simulate() # Get the samples tmp <- model_tmp_new$get_samples()

what: Set Control Parameters for iglm Estimation — control.iglm
title: Set Control Parameters for iglm Estimation — control.iglm
text: Create list control parameters `iglm` estimation algorithm.

title: Set Control Parameters for iglm Estimation — control.iglm
code: control.iglm(   estimate_model = T,   fix_x = F,   display_progress = FALSE,   return_samples = T,   offset_nonoverlap = 0,   var = FALSE,   non_stop = F,   tol = 0.001,   max_it = 100,   return_x = F,   return_y = F,   return_z = F,   accelerated = T,   cluster = NULL,   exact = F,   updated_uncertainty = T )

title: Set Control Parameters for iglm Estimation — control.iglm
text: estimate_model (logical) `TRUE` (default), main model parameters estimated. `FALSE`, estimation skipped preprocessing done. fix_x (logical) `TRUE`, 'x' predictor held fixed estimation/simulation (fixed design regression). Default `FALSE`. display_progress (logical) `TRUE`, display progress messages progress bar estimation. Default `FALSE`. return_samples (logical). TRUE (default), return simulated network/attribute samples (.e., netplus objects) generated estimation (applicable). offset_nonoverlap (numeric) value added linear predictor dyads 'overlap' set. Default `0`. var (logical) `TRUE`, attempt calculate return variance-covariance matrix estimated parameters. Default `FALSE`. non_stop (logical) `TRUE`, estimation algorithm continues `max_it` iterations, ignoring `tol` convergence criterion. Default `FALSE`. tol (numeric) tolerance level convergence. estimation stops change coefficients iterations less `tol`. Default `0.001`. max_it (integer) maximum number iterations estimation algorithm. Default `100`. return_x (logical). TRUE, return change statistics x attribute Default FALSE. samples. Default `FALSE`. (Note: `return_samples=TRUE` likely implies ). return_y (logical). TRUE, return change statistics y attribute Default FALSE. return_z (logical). TRUE, return change statistics z network. Default FALSE. accelerated (logical) `TRUE` (default), accelerated MM algorithm used based Quasi Newton scheme described Supplemental Material Fritz et al (2025). cluster parallel cluster object (e.g., `parallel` package) use potentially parallelizing parts estimation simulation. Default `NULL` (parallelization). exact (logical) `TRUE`, potentially use exact calculation method pseudo Fisher information assessing uncertainty estimates. Default `FALSE`. updated_uncertainty (logical) `TRUE` (default), potentially use updated method calculating uncertainty estimates (based mean-value theorem opposed Godambe Information).

what: Construct a iglm Model Specification Object — iglm
title: Construct a iglm Model Specification Object — iglm
text: iglm package implements comprehensive regression framework  introduced Fritz et al. (2025) studying relationships among attributes \((X, Y)\) network interference \((Z)\). based joint probability model dependent outcomes (\(Y\)) network connections \((Z)\), conditional fixed set predictors (X). approach generalizes standard Generalized Linear Models (GLMs) settings responses connections units interdependent. framework designed interpretable representing conditional distributions GLMs, scalable large networks via pseudo-likelihood convex optimization, provides insight outcome-connection dependencies (.e., spillover effects) missed conditional models. joint probability density specified exponential-family model form: $$f_{\theta}(y,z,x) \propto \Big[\prod_{=1}^{N} a_y(y_i) \exp(\theta_g^T g_i(x_i, y_i^*)) \Big] \times \Big[\prod_{\ne j} a_z(z_{,j}) \exp(\theta_h^T h_{,j}(x, y_i^*, y_j^*, z)) \Big],$$ defined two distinct sets user-specified features: \(g_i(x,y,z)\): vector actor-level functions ("g-terms")     describe relationship individual actor \(\)'s     predictors (\(x_i\)) response (\(y_i\)). \(h_{,j}(x,y,z)\): vector pair-level functions ("h-terms")     specify connections (\(z\)) responses (\(y_i, y_j\))     pair units \(\{,j\}\) depend wider     network structure. separation allows model simultaneously capture individual-level behavior (via \(g_i\)) dyadic, network-based dependencies (via \(h_{,j}\)), including local dependence limited overlapping neighborhoods (see, Fritz et al., 2025). help page documents various statistics available 'iglm', corresponding \(g_i\) (attribute-level) \(h_{,j}\) (pair-level) components joint model. user-facing constructor creating iglm_object. R6 object encompasses complete model specification, linking formula, data (netplus object), initial coefficients, MCMC sampler settings, estimation controls. serves primary input subsequent methods like $estimate() $simulate().

title: Construct a iglm Model Specification Object — iglm
code: iglm(   formula = NULL,   coef = NULL,   coef_popularity = NULL,   sampler = NULL,   control = NULL,   file = NULL )

title: Construct a iglm Model Specification Object — iglm
text: formula model `formula` object. left-hand side name `netplus` object available calling environment. See model_terms details specifying right-hand side terms. coef Optional numeric vector initial coefficients structural (non-popularity) terms `formula`. `NULL`, coefficients initialized zero. Length must match number terms. coef_popularity Optional numeric vector specifying initial popularity coefficients. Required `formula` includes popularity terms, otherwise `NULL`. Length must match `n_actor` (undirected) `2 * n_actor` (directed). sampler object class sampler_iglm, controlling MCMC sampling scheme. `NULL`, default sampler settings used. control object class control.iglm, specifying parameters estimation algorithm. `NULL`, default control settings used. file Optional character string specifying file path load previously saved  iglm_object disk (RDS format). provided, arguments ignored object loaded file.

title: Construct a iglm Model Specification Object — iglm
code: # Example usage: library(iglm) # Create a netplus data object (example) n_actors <- 50 neighborhood <- matrix(1, nrow = n_actors, ncol = n_actors) xyz_obj <- netplus(neighborhood = neighborhood, directed = FALSE,                    type_x = "binomial", type_y = "binomial") # Define ground truth coefficients gt_coef <- c("edges_local" = 3, "attribute_y" = -1, "attribute_x" = -1) gt_coef_pop <- rnorm(n = n_actors, -2, 1) # Define MCMC sampler sampler_new <- sampler.iglm(n_burn_in = 100, n_simulation = 10,                                sampler.x = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = n_actors * 10, seed = 13),                                sampler.y = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = n_actors * 10, seed = 32),                                sampler.z = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = sum(neighborhood > 0                                ) * 10, seed = 134),                                init_empty = FALSE) # Create iglm model specification model_tmp_new <- iglm(formula = xyz_obj ~ edges(mode = "local") +                           attribute_y + attribute_x + popularity,                           coef = gt_coef,                           coef_popularity = gt_coef_pop,                           sampler = sampler_new,                           control = control.iglm(accelerated = FALSE,                           max_it = 200, display_progress = TRUE, var = TRUE)) # Simulate from the model model_tmp_new$simulate() model_tmp_new$set_target(model_tmp_new$get_samples()[[1]]) #> Target netplus object has been set successfully.  # Estimate model parameters model_tmp_new$estimate() what: Model specification for a `iglm' object — model_terms
title: Model specification for a `iglm' object — model_terms
text: R package iglm implements generalized linear models (GLMs) studying relationships among attributes connected populations, responses connected units can dependent. extends GLMs independent responses dependent responses can used studying spillover connected populations network-mediated phenomena. based joint probability model dependent responses (\(Y\)) connections \((Z)\) conditional predictors (X). joint probability density specified $$f_{\theta}(y,z,x) \propto \Big[\prod_{=1}^{N} a_y(y_i) \exp(\theta_g^T g_i(x_i, y_i^*)) \Big] \times \Big[\prod_{\ne j} a_z(z_{,j}) \exp(\theta_h^T h_{,j}(x, y_i^*, y_j^*, z)) \Big],$$ defined two distinct sets user-specified features: \(g_i(x,y,z)\): vector unit-level functions ("g-terms")     describe relationship individual actor \(\)'s     predictors (\(x_i\)) response (\(y_i\)). \(h_{,j}(x,y,z)\): vector pair-level functions ("h-terms")     specify connections (\(z\)) responses (\(y_i, y_j\))     pair units \(\{,j\}\) depend wider     network structure. separation allows model simultaneously capture individual-level behavior (via \(g_i\)) dyadic, network-based dependencies (via \(h_{,j}\)), including local dependence limited overlapping neighborhoods. help page documents various statistics available 'iglm', corresponding \(g_i\) (attribute-level) \(h_{,j}\) (pair-level) components joint model. formula interface, terms can specified adding right-hand side model formula, e.g., netplus_object ~ attribute_x + edges(mode = "local") + popularity, .... See documentation iglm details model fitting estimation.

Estimation popularity effects carried using MM algorithm.      directed networks, actors sender receiver effect (assume effect actor N 0 identifiability).      undirected networks, actor single popularity effect. edges(mode = "global") Edges [h-term]: Counts different types edges. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) z_{,j}\)  mutual(mode = "global") Mutual Reciprocity [h-term]: Counts whether reciprocal tie actors \(\) \(j\) present. term used directed networks. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = z_{,j} z_{j,}\) (\(< j\)) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} z_{,j} z_{j,}\) (\(< j\)) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) z_{,j} z_{j,}\) (\(< j\))  cov_z(data, mode = "global") Dyadic Covariate [h-term]: effect dyadic covariate \(w_{,j}\) directed undirected networks. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = w_{,j} z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} w_{,j} z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) w_{,j} z_{,j}\)  cov_z_out(data, mode = "global") Covariate Sender [h-term]: effect monadic covariate \(v_{}\) sender directed network. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = v_i z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} v_i z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) v_i z_{,j}\)  cov_z_in(data, mode = "global") Covariate Receiver [h-term]: effect monadic covariate \(v_{}\) receiver directed network. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = v_j z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} v_j z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) v_j z_{,j}\)  transitive Transitivity (Local) [Joint]: statistic checking whether dyad local transitive edge, meaning exists actor \(h 
eq ,j\)     \(h\mathcal{N}_i, h\mathcal{N}_j\) \(z_{,j} = z_{,h} = z_{h,j}\): \(h_{,j} = c_{,j} z_{,j} \mathbb{}(\sum_{k} c_{,k} c_{j,k} z_{,k} z_{k,j}>1)\) 3. \(h_{,j}\) Terms Joint Attribute/Network Dependence  \( \) \(h_{,j}\) terms capture dependence attributes network. outedges_x_global() Attribute -Degree (X-Z Global) [h-term]: Models \(x_i\)'s effect -degree.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = x_i z_{,j}\). outedges_x(mode = "global") Attribute -Degree (X-Z) [Joint h-term]: Models \(x_i\)'s effect -degree. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = x_i z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} x_i z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) x_i z_{,j}\)  inedges_x(mode = "global") Attribute -Degree (X-Z) [Joint h-term]: Models \(x_j\)'s effect -degree. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = x_j z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} x_j z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) x_j z_{,j}\)  outedges_y(mode = "global") Attribute -Degree (Y-Z) [Joint h-term]: Models \(y_i\)'s effect -degree. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = y_i z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} y_i z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) y_i z_{,j}\)  inedges_y(mode = "global") Attribute -Degree (Y-Z) [Joint h-term]: Models \(y_j\)'s effect -degree. global: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = y_j z_{,j}\) local: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} y_j z_{,j}\) alocal: \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = (1 - c_{,j}) y_j z_{,j}\)  spillover_xx Symmetric X-X-Z Outcome Spillover [h-term]: Models \(x\)-outcome spillover within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} x_i x_j z_{,j}\). spillover_yy Symmetric Y-Y-Z Outcome Spillover [h-term]: Models \(y\)-outcome spillover within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} y_i y_j z_{,j}\). spillover_xy Directed X-Y-Z Treatment Spillover [h-term]: Models \(x_i \y_j\) treatment spillover within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} x_i y_j z_{,j}\). spillover_xy_symm Symmetric X-Y-Z Treatment Spillover [h-term]: Models \(x_i \leftrightarrow y_j\) treatment spillover within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} (x_i y_j + x_j y_i) z_{,j}\). spillover_yx Directed Y-X-Z Treatment Spillover [h-term]: Models \(y_i \x_j\) treatment spillover within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} y_i x_j z_{,j}\). spillover_yc Directed Y-C-Z Treatment Spillover [h-term]: Models \(y\)-treat spillover covariate \(v\)  within local neighborhood.     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} y_i v_j z_{,j}\). spillover_yc_symm(data = v) Symmetric Treatment Spillover [h-term]: Models \(v_i \leftrightarrow y_j \) treatment spillover .     Corresponds \(h_{,j}(x,y,z) = c_{,j} (v_i y_j + v_j y_i) z_{,j}\).

what: Constructor for the netplus R6 object — netplus
title: Constructor for the netplus R6 object — netplus
text: Creates `netplus` object, stores network attribute data. function acts user-friendly interface `netplus` R6 class generator. handles data input, infers parameters like number actors (`n_actor`) network directedness (`directed`) explicitly provided, processes network data consistent edgelist format, calculates overlap relation based optional neighborhood definition, performs extensive validation inputs.

title: Constructor for the netplus R6 object — netplus
code: netplus(   x_attribute = NULL,   y_attribute = NULL,   z_network = NULL,   neighborhood = NULL,   directed = NA,   n_actor = NA,   type_x = "binomial",   type_y = "binomial",   scale_x = 1,   scale_y = 1,   return_neighborhood = TRUE,   file = NULL )

title: Constructor for the netplus R6 object — netplus
text: x_attribute numeric vector first unit-level attribute. y_attribute numeric vector second unit-level attribute. z_network matrix representing network. Can 2-column edgelist square adjacency matrix. neighborhood optional matrix neighborhood representing local dependence. Can 2-column edgelist square adjacency matrix. tie `neighborhood` actor j indicates j neighborhood , implying dependence respective actors. directed logical value indicating `z_network` directed. `NA` (default), directedness inferred symmetry `z_network`. n_actor integer number actors system. `NA` (default), `n_actor` inferred attributes network matrices. type_x Character string type `x_attribute`. Must one `"binomial"`, `"poisson"`, `"normal"`. Default `"binomial"`. type_y Character string type `y_attribute`. Must one `"binomial"`, `"poisson"`, `"normal"`. Default `"binomial"`. scale_x positive numeric value scaling (e.g., variance "normal" type). Default 1. scale_y positive numeric value scaling (e.g., variance "normal" type). Default 1. return_neighborhood Logical. `TRUE` (default) `neighborhood` `NULL`, full neighborhood (dyads) generated implying global dependence. `FALSE`, neighborhood set. file (character) Optional file path load saved `netplus` object state.

what: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
title: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
text: Creates object class `sampler_iglm` (`R6`) holds parameters controlling MCMC sampling process `iglm` models. includes global settings like number simulations burn-, well references specific samplers network (`z`) attribute (`x`, `y`) components. function provides convenient way specify settings passing `iglm` constructor simulation functions.

title: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
code: sampler.iglm(   sampler.x = NULL,   sampler.y = NULL,   sampler.z = NULL,   n_simulation = 100,   n_burn_in = 10,   init_empty = TRUE,   cluster = NULL,   file = NULL )

title: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
text: sampler.x object class `sampler_net_attr` (created `sampler.net_attr()`) specifying sample `x_attribute`. `NULL` (default), default `sampler.net_attr()` settings used. sampler.y object class `sampler_net_attr` specifying sample `y_attribute`. `NULL` (default), default settings used. sampler.z object class `sampler_net_attr` specifying sample `z_network` ties *within* defined neighborhood/overlap region. `NULL` (default), default settings used. n_simulation (integer) number independent samples (networks/attributes) generate burn-period. Default: 100. Must non-negative. n_burn_in (integer) number MCMC iterations perform discard beginning chain allow reach approximate stationarity. Default: 10. Must non-negative. init_empty (logical) `TRUE` (default), initialize MCMC chain empty state (e.g., empty network, attributes zero mean). `FALSE`, starting state might depend specific implementation. cluster parallel cluster object (e.g., created `parallel::makeCluster()`) enable parallel execution simulations. `NULL` (default), simulations run sequentially. Note: Cluster management (creation/stopping) user's responsibility. file (character `NULL`) provided, loads sampler state specified .rds file instead initializing parameters.

title: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
text: object class `sampler_iglm` (`R6`).

title: Constructor for a iglm Sampler — sampler.iglm
code: n_actors <- 50 sampler_new <- sampler.iglm(n_burn_in = 100, n_simulation = 10,                                sampler.x = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = n_actors * 10, seed = 13),                                sampler.y = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = n_actors * 10, seed = 32),                                sampler.z = sampler.net_attr(n_proposals = n_actors^2, seed = 134),                                init_empty = FALSE) sampler_new #> Sampler settings #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Core parameters #>   n_simulation :10 #>   n_burn_in    :100 #>   init_empty   :FALSE #>   gibbs        :FALSE #>  #> Sub-samplers #>   sampler.x: #>     Number of proposals : 500 #>     Random seed         : 13 #>   sampler.y: #>     Number of proposals : 500 #>     Random seed         : 32 #>   sampler.z: #>     Number of proposals : 2500 #>     Random seed         : 134 # Change some values of the  sampler  sampler_new$n_simulation                                 #> [1] 10 sampler_new$set_n_simulation(100) sampler_new$n_simulation                                 #> [1] 100

See model_terms details specifying right-hand side terms. coef Numeric vector containing coefficient values structural (non-popularity) terms defined `formula`. coef_popularity Numeric vector specifying popularity coefficient values (expansiveness/attractiveness). required `formula` includes popularity terms. length must `n_actor` (undirected networks) `2 * n_actor` (directed networks), `n_actor` determined `netplus` object formula. sampler object class `sampler_iglm` (created `sampler.iglm()`) specifying MCMC sampling parameters. includes number simulations (`n_simulation`), burn-iterations (`n_burn_in`), initialization settings (`init_empty`), component sampler settings (`sampler.x`, `sampler.y`, etc.). `NULL` (default), default settings `sampler.iglm()` used. only_stats (logical). TRUE (default, consistent usage signature), function returns matrix features calculated simulation. full simulated netplus objects discarded minimize memory usage. FALSE, complete simulated netplus objects created returned within samples component output list. display_progress Logical. `TRUE`, progress messages progress bar (depending backend implementation) displayed simulation. Default `FALSE`. offset_nonoverlap Numeric scalar value passed C++ simulator. value typically added linear predictor dyads part 'overlap' set defined `netplus` object, potentially modifying tie probabilities outside primary neighborhood. Default `0`. cluster Optional parallel cluster object created, example, “parallel::makeCluster“. provided valid, function performs single burn-simulation main R process, distributes remaining `n_simulation` tasks across cluster workers using “parallel::parLapply“. Seeds component samplers offset worker ensure different random streams. `NULL` (default), simulations run sequentially main R process. fix_x Logical. `TRUE`, simulation holds `x_attribute` fixed initial state (netplus object) simulates `y_attribute` `z_network`. `FALSE` (default), components (x, y, z) simulated according model sampler settings.

Represents follower network, tie (, j) exists         legislator follows legislator j.         Self-loops (diagonal) included.  match_gender N x N matrix. matrix[, j] = 1 legislator     legislator j gender, 0 otherwise. match_race N x N matrix. matrix[, j] = 1 legislator     legislator j race, 0 otherwise. match_state N x N matrix. matrix[, j] = 1 legislator     legislator j state, 0 otherwise. white_attribute 1 x N matrix (row vector). matrix[1, ] = 1     legislator 'White', 0 otherwise. gender_attribute 1 x N matrix (row vector). matrix[1, ] = 1     legislator 'female', 0 otherwise.
